page.title: A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese Through American Movies

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Use British English|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox film | name = A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese Through American Movies | image = A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese Through American Movies.png | caption = Film poster | director = [[Martin Scorsese]]
Michael Henry Wilson | producer = Florence Dauman
Martin Scorsese | writer = Martin Scorsese
Michael Henry Wilson | starring = Martin Scorsese |studio = [[British Film Institute]] | music = [[Elmer Bernstein]] | cinematography = [[Jean-Yves Escoffier]]
[[Frances Reid (director)|Frances Reid]]
Nancy Schreiber | editing = Kenneth Levis
David Lindblom | released = {{Film date|df=y|1995|05|21|UK|1998|03|06|US}} | runtime = 225 minutes | country = United Kingdom | language = English }} '''''A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese Through American Movies''''' is a [[documentary film]] of 225 minutes in length, presented by [[Martin Scorsese]] and produced by the [[British Film Institute]]. In the film [[Martin Scorsese]] examines a selection of his favorite American films grouped according to four different types of directors: the director as storyteller; the director as an illusionist: [[D.W. Griffith]] or [[F. W. Murnau]], who created new editing techniques among other innovations that made the appearance of sound and color possible later on; the director as a smuggler— filmmakers such as [[Douglas Sirk]], [[Samuel Fuller]], and [[Vincente Minnelli]], who used to hide subversive messages in their films; and the director as an iconoclast, those filmmakers attacking social conventionalism — [[Charles Chaplin]], [[Erich von Stroheim]], [[Orson Welles]], [[Elia Kazan]], [[Nicholas Ray]], [[Stanley Kubrick]], [[Arthur Penn]], and [[Sam Peckinpah]]. The documentary is structured in segments: *Part I **The director's dilemma **The director as storyteller ***The Western ***The Gangster film ***The Musical *Part II **The director as illusionist **The director as smuggler I *Part III **The director as smuggler II **The director as iconoclast It was originally shown in three parts on [[Channel 4]] in the UK in 1995. ==Films mentioned== (Roughly in the order of the appearance.) --Part I-- *''[[The Bad and the Beautiful]]'', 1952, directed by [[Vincente Minnelli]] *''[[Duel in the Sun (film)|Duel in the Sun]]'', nicknamed ''"Lust in the Dust"'', 1946 [[Western film]] directed by [[King Vidor]], [[William Dieterle]] and others *''[[The Girl Can't Help It]]'', 1956 [[Musical film]] directed by [[Frank Tashlin]] *''[[Bigger Than Life]]'', 1956 directed by [[Nicholas Ray]] *''[[Vertigo (film)|Vertigo]]'', 1958 psychological thriller film directed by [[Alfred Hitchcock]] *''[[The Naked Kiss]]'', 1964 neo-noir film written and directed by [[Samuel Fuller]] *''[[Murder by Contract]]'', 1958 [[film noir]] directed by [[Irving Lerner]] *''[[The Red House (film)|The Red House]]'', 1947 psychological thriller directed by [[Delmer Daves]] *''[[The Phenix City Story]]'', 1955 [[film noir]] directed by Phil Karlson *''[[Sullivan's Travels]]'', 1941 comedy film written and directed by [[Preston Sturges]] *''[[The Crowd (1928 film)|The Crowd]]'', 1928 [[silent film]] directed by [[King Vidor]] *''[[The Big Parade]]'', 1925 [[silent film]] directed by [[King Vidor]] *''[[Shadow of a Doubt]]'', 1943 thriller film directed by [[Alfred Hitchcock]] *''[[Mr. Smith Goes to Washington]]'', 1939, directed by [[Frank Capra]] *''[[The Great Train Robbery (1903 film)|The Great Train Robbery]]'', 1903 [[Western film]] written, produced, and directed by [[Edwin S. Porter]] *''[[The Musketeers of Pig Alley]]'', 1912, directed by [[D. W. Griffith]] *''[[High Sierra (film)|High Sierra]]'', 1941, directed by [[Raoul Walsh]] *''[[Colorado Territory (film)|Colorado Territory]]'', 1949 [[western film]] directed by [[Raoul Walsh]] (a remake of the 1941 ''[[High Sierra (film)|High Sierra]]'') *''[[Stagecoach (1939 film)|Stagecoach]]'', 1939 [[western film]] directed by [[John Ford]] *''[[She Wore a Yellow Ribbon]]'', 1949 [[western film]] directed by [[John Ford]] *''[[The Searchers (film)|The Searchers]]'', 1956 [[western film]] directed by [[John Ford]] *''[[The Furies (1950 film)|The Furies]]'', 1950 American [[Western film]] directed by [[Anthony Mann]] *''[[The Naked Spur]]'', 1953 American [[Western film]] directed by [[Anthony Mann]] *''[[The Tall T]]'', 1957 [[Western film]] directed by [[Budd Boetticher]] *''[[The Left Handed Gun]]'', 1958 American [[western film]] and the film directorial debut of [[Arthur Penn]] *''[[Unforgiven]]'', 1992 American Western film produced and directed by [[Clint Eastwood]] *''[[Chesty: A Tribute to a Legend]]'', 1971 documentary directed by [[John Ford]] *''[[The Public Enemy]]'', 1931 American Pre-Code crime film directed by [[William A. Wellman]] *''[[Regeneration (1915 film)|Regeneration]]'', 1915, directed by [[Raoul Walsh]] *''[[Scarface (1932 film)|Scarface]]'', 1932 American gangster film directed by [[Howard Hawks]] (and [[Richard Rosson (filmmaker)|Richard Rosson]]) *''[[The Roaring Twenties]]'', 1939 crime thriller directed by [[Raoul Walsh]] *''[[I Walk Alone]]'', 1948 [[film noir]] directed by [[Byron Haskin]]. *''[[Force of Evil]]'', 1948 [[film noir]] directed by [[Abraham Polonsky]] *''[[Point Blank (1967 film)|Point Blank]]'', 1967 American crime film directed by [[John Boorman]] *''[[Gold Diggers of 1935]]'', 1935 [[musical film]] directed and choreographed by Busby Berkeley *''[[Gold Diggers of 1933]]'', 1933 [[musical film]] directed by [[Mervyn LeRoy]], staged and choreographed by [[Busby Berkeley]] *''[[42nd Street (film)|42nd Street]]'', 1933 [[musical film]] directed by [[Lloyd Bacon]] with choreography by [[Busby Berkeley]] *''[[Footlight Parade]]'', 1933 [[musical film]] directed by [[Lloyd Bacon]] with choreography by [[Busby Berkeley]] *''[[Meet Me in St. Louis]]'', 1944 [[musical film]] directed by [[Vincente Minnelli]] *''[[My Dream Is Yours]]'', 1949 [[musical film|musical]] and [[Comedy film|comedy]] film directed by [[Michael Curtiz]] **''[[New York, New York (1977 film)|New York, New York]]'', 1977 [[musical film|musical]] directed by [[Martin Scorsese]] (film mentioned in connection with ''[[My Dream Is Yours]]'') *''[[The Band Wagon]]'', 1953 [[musical film]] directed by [[Vincente Minnelli]] *''[[A Star Is Born (1954 film)|A Star Is Born]]'', 1954 [[musical film]] directed by [[George Cukor]] *''[[All That Jazz (film)|All That Jazz]]'', 1979 [[musical film]] directed by [[Bob Fosse]] —Part II-- *''[[The Cameraman]]'', 1928 [[silent film|silent]] [[comedy]] directed by [[Edward Sedgwick]] and an uncredited [[Buster Keaton]] *''[[The Birth of a Nation]]'', 1915 [[silent film]] directed by [[D. W. Griffith]] *''[[Death's Marathon]]'', 1913 [[silent film]] directed by [[D. W. Griffith]] *''[[Cabiria]]'', 1914 Italian [[silent film]] directed by [[Giovanni Pastrone]] *''[[Intolerance (film)|Intolerance]]'', 1916 [[silent film]] directed by [[D. W. Griffith]] *''[[The Ten Commandments (1923 film)|The Ten Commandments (1923)]]'', 1923 [[silent film]] directed by [[Cecil B. DeMille]] *''[[Samson and Delilah (1949 film)|Samson and Delilah]]'', 1949, directed by [[Cecil B. DeMille]] *''[[The Ten Commandments (1956 film)|The Ten Commandments (1956)]]'', 1956, directed by [[Cecil B. DeMille]] *''[[Sunrise: A Song of Two Humans]]'', 1927 [[silent film]] directed by [[F. W. Murnau]] *''[[Seventh Heaven (1927 film)|Seventh Heaven]]'', 1927 [[silent film]] directed by [[Frank Borzage]] *''[[Anna Christie (1930 film)|Anna Christie]]'', 1930, directed by [[Clarence Brown]] *''[[Her Man (film)|Her Man]]'', 1930, directed by [[Tay Garnett]] *''[[The Big House (1930 film)|The Big House]]'', 1930, directed by [[George W. Ulmer]] *''[[Double Indemnity (film)|Double Indemnity]]'', 1944 [[film noir]] directed by [[Billy Wilder]] *''[[Crime Wave (1954 film)|Crime Wave]]'', 1954 [[film noir]] directed by [[André De Toth]] *''[[Outrage (1950 film)|Outrage]]'', 1950, directed by noted [[film noir]] actress and pioneering female director [[Ida Lupino]] *''[[Gun Crazy]]'', 1950 [[film noir]] directed by [[Joseph H. {{Infobox circus | name = Al G. Barnes Circus | image =[[Image:Truly Big Show.JPG|300px]] | caption = | circus_name = Al G. Barnes Circus | country = United States | founder = [[Alpheus George Barnes Stonehouse]] | year = 1895 | operator = | fate = Purchased by the [[American Circus Corporation]] in 1929. Stopped touring after 1938. | ringmaster = | traveling = | tent = | number = | winter = | acts = | other = | website = }}
'''Al G. Barnes Circus''' was an American circus run by [[Alpheus George Barnes Stonehouse]].
==History== Stonehouse started his show in 1895 with a pony, a phonograph, and a [[stereopticon]].<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Died |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,846966-2,00.html |quote=Alpheus George Barnes Stonehouse (Al G. Barnes), 68, circusman, founder and longtime owner of Barnes's Circus; after a lingering illness; in [[Indio, California]]. He started his show in 1895 with a pony, a phonograph, a stereopticon. A colorful participant at every performance, he would lead the opening parade seated on the head of a mammoth elephant. Two years ago he sold his interests to Circusman John Ringling for $1,000,000. |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |date=August 3, 1931 |accessdate=2008-07-22 }}</ref> By 1929, the "Al G. Barnes Wild Animal Show" had grown to 5-rings and it was purchased by the [[American Circus Corporation]]. American Circus already owned the [[Sells-Floto Circus]], [[John Robinson Shows]], [[Hagenbeck-Wallace Circus]], and [[Sparks Circus]]. That same year [[John Nicholas Ringling|John Ringling]], the owner of the [[Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Circus]], bought out the American Circus Corporation.<ref name=acc>{{cite web |url=http://www.ringling.com/ContentPage.aspx?id=45833&section=45825 |title=Bailey and the Ringlings |accessdate=2013-11-29 |quote=In 1929, reacting to the fact that his competitor, the American Circus Corporation, had signed a contract to perform in New York's Madison Square Garden, Ringling purchased [[American Circus]] for $1.7-million. In one fell swoop, Ringling had absorbed five major shows: [[Sells-Floto]], [[Al G. Barnes]], Sparks, [[Hagenbeck-Wallace]], and John Robinson. |publisher=[[Feld Entertainment]] }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Man Who Started as a Clown Now Controls the Entire Big Top Industry. |url=https://select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=FB0E1EFD3454167A93C2A81782D85F4D8285F9 |quote=John Ringling, head of the Ringling Brothers-Barnum Bailey Combined Circus, has purchased the five circuses, with Winter quarters, of the American Circus Corporation, it was learned yesterday. |work=[[The New York Times]] |date=September 10, 1929 |accessdate=2009-02-12 }}</ref>
The five circuses that were part of that acquisition continued to tour under their own names, but were closed one-by-one during the [[Great Depression]]. In 1937 the Al G. Barnes Wild Animal Show and Sells Floto were combined into one circus. That circus, Al G. Barnes Sells-Floto toured in 1937 and 1938.<ref>http://www.circushistory.org/Routes/BarnesSells1937.htm</ref>
In 1938 the co-owned Ringling Bros and Barnum & Bailey Combined Shows was experiencing labor problems which ultimately led to the circus being closed after performances in [[Scranton, Pennsylvania]] on June 22.<ref>http://archives.chicagotribune.com/1938/06/27/page/6/article/circus-packs-up-after-strike-to-go-back-to-base</ref> After regrouping at the circus winter quarters in [[Sarasota, Florida]] the Ringling-Barnum circus trains were dispatched to [[Redfield, South Dakota]] where the two circuses met and were combined into a yet larger circus featuring many of the major stars from Ringling-Barnum. The circus toured from July 11 until November 27, 1938 as "Al G. Barnes and Sells-Floto Circus Presenting Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Stupendous New Features''.<ref>http://www.circushistory.org/Routes/BarnesSells1937.htm#1938</ref> ''Among the attractions that were featured were big game hunter "Bring 'em Back Alive [[Frank Buck (animal collector)|Frank Buck]]" and [[Gargantua (gorilla)]]. When the show finished its season however, rather than returning to its own winter quarters in [[Baldwin Park, California]], the circus trains traveled to the Ringling winter quarters near [[Sarasota, Florida]], never to emerge again.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Duble|first=Charles E.|title=Passing of Circuses from the American Scene|journal=Bandwagon|date=July 1957|volume=1|issue=2|pages=4|url=http://www.circushistory.org/Bandwagon/bw-1957Jul.htm|accessdate=30 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Bradbury|first=Joseph T.|journal=[[Bandwagon (magazine)|Bandwagon]]|date=Jul–Aug 1963|volume=7|issue=4|pages=3–6|url=http://www.circushistory.org/Bandwagon/bw-1963Jul.htm|title=The Al G. Barnes Winter Quarters at Baldwin Park, Calif.|accessdate=14 January 2015}}</ref>''
One of their more famous animals was [[Black Diamond (elephant)|Black Diamond]], an [[Indian elephant]] whose unpredictable temper resulted in the deaths of several people and was shot between 50-100 times in 1929, before his own death.<ref>{{cite news |first= |last= |authorlink= |coauthors= |title=Black Diamond |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,752326,00.html |quote=Curley Pickett has been a farm hand for the last two years in Corsicana, Tex. Before that he was an elephant trainer for the Al. G. Barnes circus where his special charge was Black Diamond, a land elephant. Last week Farm Hand Pickett, learning that the old circus was coming to town, invited his employer, Mrs. Eva Donohue, to see Black Diamond. ... Black Diamond spied them, gave Pickett a malevolent look, wrapped him in his trunk and tossed him over a box car. The nine-ton beast then smashed Mrs. Donohue to the ground, trampled the life out of her. When Pickett had been sent to the hospital, keepers held a council, wired to Circus Owner John Ringling for advice. Mr. Ringling condemned Black Diamond to death. ...|work=[[Time magazine]] |date=October 28, 1929 |accessdate=2009-02-12 }}</ref>
==Performers== Although the Al G. Barnes Circus featured many traditional acts associated with circuses, it was known for its wild animal acts. [[Mabel Stark]], the tiger trainer was associated with the circus for many years.<ref>http://mentalfloss.com/article/48808/mabel-stark-lady-tigers</ref> Stark joined the circus in 1911, first presenting a horse act. In 1916 she began presenting tigers in the center ring of the wild animal show. Although she left the circus in 1922, she returned in 1930.<ref>http://www.circusesandsideshows.com/performers/mabelstark.html</ref> Bert Nelson was another wild animal trainer who appeared on the circus in the late 1930s.<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=fCgDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA40&lpg=PA40&dq=bert+nelson+al+g.+barnes&source=bl&ots=Il6g3Bv4Ta&sig=v25wkxW33L2GdnTmDdHJaYgKocU&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiesMLBxZvMAhVS3WMKHeKhCHAQ6AEIXDAN#v=onepage&q=bert%20nelson%20al%20g.%20barnes&f=false</ref> For many seasons, the elephants were trained and presented by Frank "Cheerful" Gardner.<ref>http://www.circushistory.org/History/Barnes1922.htm</ref><ref>http://bucklesw.blogspot.com/2005/09/cheerful-gardner-3.html</ref> [[Eddie Woenecker]] became the circus' bandmaster in 1913 and stayed with the circus through 1922. He returned to the circus in 1936 and continued to perform in that capacity through the 1938 season.<ref>https://books.google.com/books?id=vB4EAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA69&lpg=PA69&dq=eddie+Woeckener+barnes+circus&source=bl&ots=8DCuHiwSY8&sig=cHETEtW_xJH4peMDvS4BBaNThsE&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjD7MqayZvMAhUEz2MKHcRpD-kQ6AEIKDAC#v=onepage&q=eddie%20Woeckener%20barnes%20circus&f=false</ref>
==Winter Quarters and Barnes City Zoo== In 1914 the Al G. Barnes Circus began wintering in [[Venice, California]] near the Venice lagoon. It continued to winter at that location until November 1920 when the circus trains returned for the winter to a new location on Washington Boulevard between Venice and [[Culver City, California]]. The Al G. Barnes Circus was known as a "Wild Animal Show," and in December 1923 the "Barnes Circus Zoo" opened at the corner of Washington Boulevard and McLaughlin Avenue in Culver City. The Zoo cost 79,000 to build and at the time was kept open even when the show was touring. The area where the winter quarters and zoo were located were incorporated into the short-lived town of [[Barnes City, California]]. The area was eventually annexed into both Culver City in 1925 and [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]] in 1926.<ref>http://www.westland.net/venicehistory/articles/BarnesCircusZoo.htm</ref>
Following the annexation of the winter quarters property, Barnes relocated his winter quarters into an unincorporated area in the [[San Gabriel Valley]] in 1927. The 300 acres were on Valley Boulevard midway between Baldwin Park and El Monte. From 1927 until 1938 the circus returned to the Baldwin Park quarters, however at two separate locations.<ref>http://www.circushistory.org/Bandwagon/bw-1963Jul.htm</ref> At the conclusion of the 1932 season the show unloaded about a half mile east of the original location and that is where it remained until 1938 when most of the equipment was transferred to the Ringling winter quarters in Sarasota at the end of the season.
==''King of the Jungle''== ''[[King of the Jungle (1933 film)|King of the Jungle]]'' is a 1933 [[Paramount Pictures]] film that includes animals, performers and scenes from the Al G. Barnes Circus and winter quarters in 1932. Although the movie is set on the lot of "Corey's Circus," it was actually filmed on location at the first Baldwin Park winter quarters. Several acts from the circus that season are featured, including Mabel Stark's tiger act. The tigers are mid-performance at the time that the big top catches fire during the film's climatic moments.<ref>http://www.circushistory.org/Bandwagon/bw-1963Jul.htm</ref>
==Notable Events== On May 15, 1922, a large circus elephant known as [[Tusko]] escaped from the Al G. Barnes Circus while it was in [[Sedro-Woolley, Washington]]. The elephant demolished fences, knocked over laundry lines and trees, telephone poles, and overturned a [[Model T]].<ref>{{cite news |author= |coauthors= |title=Death Takes Tusko, Big Elephant That Lived Stormy Life |url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/chicagotribune/access/474766192.html?dids=474766192:474766192&FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Jun+11,+1933&author=&pub=Chicago+Tribune&desc=DEATH+TAKES+TUSKO,+BIG+ELEPHANT+THAT+LIVED+STORMY+LIFE&pqatl=google |quote=Tusko one of the largest and most publicized elephants In captivity survived hundreds of death threats and other perils brought on by his temperament only ... |work=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=June 11, 1933 |accessdate=2010-10-16 }}</ref>
In July 1930, a train wreck happened In the Canadian Province of [[New Brunswick]] near the city of [[Moncton]] in the small community of [[Canaan Station, New Brunswick|Canaan Station]], killing 4 people and injuring several others.<ref>[https://johnwood1946.wordpress.com/2013/07/10/1930-circus-train-wreck-near-moncton/Circus Train Wreck], Near Moncton.</ref>
==Names== *Al G. Barnes Circus *Al G. Barnes Wild Animal Circus *Al G. Barnes and Sells-Floto Circus (1937–38) *Al G. Barnes and Sells-Floto Circus Presenting Ringling Bros. and Barnum & Bailey Features (1938)
==External links== *[http://freepages.genealogy.rootsweb.ancestry.com/~esthersgenealogypage/al_g_barnes.html Alpheus George Barnes Stonehouse] *[http://www.westland.net/venicehistory/articles/BarnesCircusZoo.htm Barnes Circus Zoo]

''For the new opera house in Algiers, see [[Algiers Opera House]].'' {{Infobox building | name = Théâtre National Algérien Mahieddine Bachtarzi | native_name= | image = Photo theatre national algerien 30102014.jpg | caption = The Mahieddine Bachtazi Theatre in 2014 | former_names = | alternate_names = | building_type = | architectural_style = | structural_system = | cost = | location = | address = | location_town = Algiers | location_country = Algeria | iso_region = | client = | owner = | current_tenants = | landlord = | coordinates = | altitude = | start_date = 1850 | completion_date = 1853 | inauguration_date = | demolition_date = | height = | diameter = | other_dimensions = | floor_count = | floor_area = | main_contractor = | architect = [[Charles Frédéric Chassériau]]
[[Justin Ponsard]] | structural_engineer = | services_engineer = | civil_engineer = | other_designers = | quantity_surveyor = | awards = | references = }} The '''Théâtre National Algérien Mahieddine Bachtarzi''', formerly known as the '''Algiers Opera House''', is a historic building in [[Algiers]], Algeria. It was built from 1850 to 1853.{{cite book|last1=Auzias|first1=Dominique|last2=Labourdette|first2=Jean-Paul|title=Algérie|date=2015|publisher=Nouvelles éditions de l'Université|location=Paris|page=170|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=SS-VBgAAQBAJ&pg=PA170&dq=Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre+national+alg%C3%A9rien&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjx7b7-o8TPAhUHFx4KHdWLCdsQ6AEIVzAJ#v=onepage&q=Th%C3%A9%C3%A2tre%20national%20alg%C3%A9rien&f=false}} It was designed by architects [[Charles Frédéric Chassériau]] and [[Justin Ponsard]] in the [[Baroque Revival architecture|Baroque Revival]] style. After it caught fire in 1883, it was rebuilt. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.tna.dz/ Official website] {{coord|36.7811|N|3.0603|E|source:wikidata|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Theatre National Algerien Mahieddine Bachtarzi}} [[Category:Buildings and structures completed in 1853]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Algiers]] [[Category:Baroque Revival architecture in Algeria]] [[Category:Opera houses in Algeria]] [[Category:Theatres in Algeria]] {{Algeria-struct-stub}}

Independent (Lagos)|The Daily Independent]]|accessdate=4 March 2011|location=Lagos, Nigeria}}{{cite news|url=http://www.dailytrust.com.ng/weekly/index.php/entertainment/4608-anchor-baby-and-the-dark-underbelly-of-the-american-dream|title=Anchor Baby and the dark underbelly of the American Dream|date=12 February 2011|work=[[Daily Trust]]|accessdate=4 March 2011|location=Abuja, Nigeria}} == Plot == A married [[Nigerian]] couple, Joyce and Paul Unanga, living [[Undocumented immigrant|illegally]] in the [[United States]], has been ordered to leave the country by [[Immigration and Customs Enforcement|U.S. immigration]]. They decide that they will leave, but only after Joyce, who is five months pregnant, delivers her baby in the United States to guarantee automatic U.S. citizenship for their child. Thus ignoring the deportation order, the couple goes into hiding. When Paul is caught and deported, leaving Joyce to fend for herself, she struggles on her own to survive. Bureaucracy keeps getting in the way of Joyce achieving her goal and just as she is about to give up hope, she meets Susan, a married freelance writer who offers to help in the form of safe, free accommodation until the baby is born. With the help of her newfound friend, Joyce sets out to make the 'American Dream' come true for her unborn child.{{cite web|url=http://www.paff.org/panafricanfilmfestival/anchor-baby/ |title=Anchor Baby |publisher=[[Pan-African Film Festival]] |accessdate=4 March 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110215035618/http://www.paff.org/panafricanfilmfestival/anchor-baby/ |archivedate=15 February 2011 }}{{cite news|url=http://www.tribune.com.ng/index.php/weekend-starter/8976-pregnant-star-actress-omoni-oboli-ordered-out-of-us-struggles-to-gain-citizenship-for-her-unborn-child |title=Pregnant star actress, Omoni Oboli, ordered out of US •Struggles to gain citizenship for her unborn child |last=Idowu |first=Ayo |date=30 July 2010 |work=[[Nigerian Tribune]] |accessdate=10 March 2011 |location=Lagos, Nigeria |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110724143233/http://www.tribune.com.ng/index.php/weekend-starter/8976-pregnant-star-actress-omoni-oboli-ordered-out-of-us-struggles-to-gain-citizenship-for-her-unborn-child |archivedate=24 July 2011 }} ==Cast== * [[Omoni Oboli]] - Joyce Unanga * [[Sam Sarpong]] - Paul Unanga * Terri Oliver - Susan Backley ==See also== * [[List of Nigerian films of 2010]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{Official website|http://www.anchorbabymovie.com/}} * {{IMDb title|1666555|Anchor Baby}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Anchor Baby}} [[Category:2010 films]] [[Category:Nigerian drama films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:2010s drama films]] [[Category:Films about illegal immigration to the United States]] [[Category:Films shot in Canada]] [[Category:Films set in the United States]] [[Category:Films by Nigerian directors]] [[Category:Nigerian thriller films]] [[Category:Nigerian films]]

{{Use Australian English|date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist | | name = Archie Roach | image = Archie Roach 2016.jpg | caption = Roach in 2016 | background = solo_singer | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1956|1|8|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Mooroopna]], Victoria, Australia | death_date = | birth_name = Archibald William Roach | origin = | instrument = Vocals, [[six-string guitar]] | genre = [[Alternative rock]], [[world music]], roots | occupation = Musician, songwriter | years_active = 1980s – present | label = [[Mushroom Records]]
[[Liberation Music]]
[[ABC Music]] | associated_acts = The Altogethers
[[Ruby Hunter]] | website = }} '''Archibald William "Archie" Roach''', [[Order of Australia|AM]]{{cite web | url=http://www.smh.com.au/national/queens-birthday-honours-2015-full-list-20150607-ghgydh.html | publisher=Sydney Morning Herald | date= 8 June 2015 | title=Queen's birthday honours}} (born 8 January 1956, [[Mooroopna]]){{cite web | archiveurl = http://pandora.nla.gov.au/nph-wb/20010123130000/http://www.historysmiths.com.au/CentFedPlayKit/biogs/nature/roach_archie.htm | url = http://www.historysmiths.com.au/CentFedPlayKit/biogs/nature/roach_archie.htm | title = Roach, Archie | last = Roach | first = Archie | publisher = HistorySmiths. [[National Library of Australia]] | year = 1999 | archivedate = 23 January 2001 | accessdate = 26 February 2014 }} is an Australian musician. He is a singer, songwriter and guitarist, as well as a campaigner for the rights of [[Indigenous Australians]]. Roach's debut solo album, ''[[Charcoal Lane]]'', was released in 1990. It featured the song "[[Took the Children Away]]", which was added to the [[National Film and Sound Archive]]'s [[Sounds of Australia]] registry in 2013.{{cite web|url=http://nfsa.gov.au/collection/sound/sounds-australia/complete-list/ |title=National Film and Sound Archive|publisher=Sounds of Australia|accessdate=28 September 2018}} Also in 2013 he won a [[Deadly Award]] for Lifetime Contribution to Healing the [[Stolen Generations]] as well as for Album of the Year. Along with fellow Deadly winner [[Pat O'Shane]], he called for an end to the [[Northern Territory Intervention]].{{cite web|url=http://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/deadly-archie-wants-action-from-abbott-20130910-2ti6m.html|title=Deadly Archie wants action from Abbott|publisher=[[Sydney Morning Herald]]|date=10 September 2013|accessdate=28 September 2018}} Roach has toured around the globe, headlining and opening shows for [[Joan Armatrading]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Billy Bragg]], [[Tracy Chapman]], [[Suzanne Vega]] and [[Patti Smith]].{{cite web|url=https://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/entertainment/aboriginal-singer-archie-roach-recovering-from-stroke/news-story/57c01c07d30f9a10c2b2f584a3ee5449|title= Aboriginal singer Archie Roach recovering from stroke|publisher=Daily Telegraph|date=16 October 2018 |accessdate=28 September 2018}} == Life and career== ===1956-1980s: Early life=== Archibald William Roach was born on 8 January 1956 in [[Mooroopna, Victoria]]. Mooroopna is named after an [[Indigenous Australian|Aboriginal]] word referring to a bend in the [[Goulburn River (Victoria)|Goulburn River]], near [[Shepparton, Victoria|Shepparton]] in central Victoria. According to Roach, "My name is Archie Roach and I represent 'Nature's gifts' because my song "Took the Children Away" won a human rights award. My lyrics draw attention to, the hardship and humiliation suffered by many Indigenous Australians." In 1956, Roach's family, along with the rest of the area's Indigenous population, were re-housed on Rumbalara [[Mission (Christian)|mission]]. Roach and his family subsequently moved to [[Framlingham, Victoria|Framlingham]], where his mother had been born.Roach, A. (2002) lyrics to "Move It On" on ''Sensual Being'' At the age of 4, Roach and his sisters, along with the other Indigenous Australian children of the [[stolen generations]], were forcibly removed from their family by Australian government agencies and placed in an [[orphanage]].{{cite web|url=https://www.portrait.gov.au/portraits/2010.90/archie-roach|title=Archie Roach, 1992 (printed 2010)|publisher=portrait|date=2010|accessdate=28 September 2018}} After two unpleasant placements in [[foster care]], Roach was eventually [[Foster care|fostered]] by Alex and Dulcie Cox, a family of Scottish immigrants in [[Melbourne, Victoria|Melbourne]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2018-07-12/archie-roach-a-life-in-song/9957168|title=From stolen child to Indigenous leader: Archie Roach sings the songs that signpost his life |publisher=ABC|date= 12 July 2018|accessdate=28 September 2018}} Alex Cox would sing traditional ballads and introduced Roach to guitar and keyboards. Roach said "He was a big influence on me — a good influence. I'll love him to the day I die." At the age of fifteen, Roach was contacted by his natural sister, who told him their birth mother had just died. He spent the next fourteen years on the streets, battling alcoholism. Roach met his future wife, [[Ruby Hunter]], at a Salvation Army drop-in centre when she was sixteen. ===1989-2000 : ''Charcoal Lane'', ''Jamu Dreaming'' and ''Looking for Butter Boy''=== {{main|Charcoal Lane|Jamu Dreaming|Looking for Butter Boy}} In the late 1980s, Roach and Hunter formed a band, the Altogethers, with several other Indigenous Australians and moved to Melbourne. Roach wrote his first song, "[[Took the Children Away]]", which he performed on a community radio station in Melbourne and on an Indigenous current affairs program in 1988. Australian musician [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]] invited Roach to open his concert early in 1989, where he performed "Took the Children Away", a song telling the story of the Stolen Generations and his own experience of being forcibly removed from his family. His performance was met with stunned silence, followed by shattering applause. In 1990, with the encouragement of Kelly, Roach recorded his debut solo album, ''[[Charcoal Lane]]'', which was released in May 1990. The album was certified gold and awarded two [[ARIA Awards]] at the 1991 ceremony. The album included "Took the Children Away" which became one of the most important songs in Australia's contemporary history.{{cite web|url=http://ruminating.org/culture/archie-roachs-song-took-the-children-away/|title= Archie Roach’s song: ‘Took the Children Away’|publisher=Rumington|date=July 2014|accessdate=28 September 2018}} In 1992, it won an international Human Rights Achievement Award and featured in the top 50 albums for 1992 by ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' magazine. In May 1993, Roach released his second studio album, ''[[Jamu Dreaming]]''. The album was recorded with musical assistance from [[David Bridie]], [[Tiddas (band)|Tiddas]], [[Paul Kelly (Australian musician)|Paul Kelly]], [[Vika and Linda Bull]], [[Ruby Hunter]], [[Dave Arden]] and [[Joe Geia]].{{cite web|url=https://www.abcmusic.com.au/archie-roach|title=Artist Archie Roach|publisher=ABC|date= 2010|accessdate=28 September 2018}} The album peaked at number 55 on the ARIA Charts. In 1995, Roach toured extensively throughout the US, Canada, the UK and Europe. He returned to Australia to record the title track for ATSIC's Native Title CD, ''Our Home, Our Land'', with Tiddas, Kev Carmody, Bart Willoughby, Shane Howard and Bunna Laurie. In 1996, Roach performed as part of a presentation to the Human Rights Commission's Inquiry into the Stolen Generations, before embarking on a national tour as a guest of [[Tracy Chapman]].{{cite web|url=https://www.deadlyvibe.com.au/2007/11/archie-roach/|title=Archie Roach Deadly|publisher=Deadly|date=November 2007|accessdate=10 October 2018}} In October 1997, Roach released his third studio album, ''[[Looking for Butter Boy]]'', which was recorded on his traditional land at Port Fairy in south-western Victoria. The album's lead single, "[[Hold On Tight (Archie Roach song)|Hold On Tight]]", won the [[ARIA Award for Best Indigenous Release]] in 1997 and the album won the same award at the 1998 award ceremony. ===2001-2009: ''Sensual Being'' and ''Journey'', death of Ruby Hunter === {{main|Sensual Being|Journey (Archie Roach album)|1988 (Archie Roach album)}} In July 2002, Roach released his fourth studio album, ''[[Sensual Being]]'', which peaked at number 59 on the ARIA charts. In 2002, he worked on the [[Rolf de Heer]] film ''[[The Tracker]]''. In 2004, Roach and Hunter collaborated with the [[Australian Art Orchestra]] and [[Paul Grabowsky]] to create a musical experience titled ''[[Ruby (Archie Roach, Ruby Hunter, Paul Grabowsky and Australian Art Orchestra album)|Ruby]]''. ''Ruby'' tells the story of Ruby Hunter from her birth near a billabong on the banks of the Murray River, through the stolen generation, search for identity and the discovery of hope through love. In 2004, it won The [[Deadly Award|Deadly Awards]] for "Excellence in Film & Theatrical Score".{{cite web|url=http://www.aao.com.au/rubysstory/|title=Ruby's Story |publisher=AAO|accessdate=28 September 2018}} In October 2007, Roach released ''[[Journey (Archie Roach album)|Journey]]'', an album of songs as a companion piece to a documentary film called ''Liyarn Ngarn'', made with Roach, Patrick Dodson and Pete Postlethwaite.{{cite web|url=http://www.captainstomp.com/music/cd/archie-roach-journey|title=Archie Roach - Journey Archie's 2007 Studio Album on CD|publisher=Captain Stomp|accessdate=28 September 2018}} In November 2009, ABC Music released previously unreleased Roach recordings from 1988 under the album title ''[[1988 (Archie Roach album)|1988]]''. ===2010-present: ''Into the Bloodstream'' and ''Let Love Rule'' === {{main|Into the Bloodstream|Creation (Archie Roach album)|Let Love Rule (Archie Roach album)}} [[File:Archie Roach.jpg|thumb|right|Roach performing at [[WOMADelaide]] in 2011.]] In October 2012, Roach released ''[[Into the Bloodstream]]'', an album he described as being built on pain following the death of his wife in February 2010. {{cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/entertainment/music/out-of-the-pain-a-spirit-rises-20121019-27w4a.html|title=Out of the pain, a spirit rises |publisher=SMH|date=19 October 2010|accessdate=28 September 2018}} In October 2013, Roach released ''[[Creation (Archie Roach album)|Creation]]'', a 4-CD box set of his first four studio albums. The album was released to coincide with the premiere of Roach's new live show, also entitled Creation, which debuted at the inaugural Boomerang Festival in Byron Bay from 4-6 October 2013.{{cite web|url=https://www.facebook.com/archieroach/photos/archie-roach-4cd-set-creation-is-out-nowreleased-to-coincide-with-the-premiere-o/10153339202625118/|title= ARCHIE ROACH 4CD SET ‘CREATION’ IS OUT NOW!|publisher=Facebook|date= 3 October 2013|accessdate=10 October 2018}} At the [[APRA Music Awards of 2015]] 2015, Roach (and [[Shane Howard]]) won Best Original Song Composed for the Screen "The Secret River" from ''[[The Secret River (TV series)|The Secret River]]''.{{cite web|url=http://apraamcos.com.au/awards/2015-awards/screen-music-awards/best-original-song-composed-for-the-screen/|title=2015 SCREEN MUSIC AWARDS |publisher=APRA AMCOS|date=2015|accessdate=28 September 2018}} In November 2015, Roach celebrated the 25th anniversary of ''[[Charcoal Lane]]'' with a deluxe remastered edition. The new edition included a second disc featuring previously unreleased ''Triple J - [[Live At The Wireless]]'' recordings and new interpretations of classic ''Charcoal Lane'' material by various artists. In November and December 2015, Roach undertook a national tour to celebrate the album's 25th anniversary.{{cite web|url=https://www.jbhifi.com.au/music/browse/singer-songwriter/charcoal-lane-25th-anniversary-edition/682557/|title= Charcoal Lane (25th Anniversary Edition)|publisher=JBHiFi|accessdate=28 September 2018}} In November 2016, Roach released his seventh studio album, ''[[Let Love Rule (Archie Roach album)|Let Love Rule]]'', which peaked at number 24 on the ARIA Charts, becoming his highest charting album to date. At the [[APRA Music Awards of 2017]] in March 2017, Roach won the Ted Albert Award for Outstanding Services to Australian Music.{{cite web|url=http://apraamcos.com.au/news/2017/march/archie-roach-receives-ted-albert-award/|title=Archie Roach Receives Ted Albert Award|publisher=APRA AMCOS|date=27 March 2017|accessdate=28 September 2018}} In April 2018, Roach performed at the [[2018 Commonwealth Games|Commonwealth Games]] Closing Ceremony on the Gold Coast with [[Amy Shark]].{{cite web|url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/sport/commonwealth-games/commonwealth-games-closing-ceremony-a-disastrous-finish-to-a-brilliant-event/news-story/1c4d9ed1c97e5a863e12fc6dd006249d|title=Commonwealth Games closing ceremony a disastrous finish to a brilliant event |publisher=Courier Mail|date=15 April 2018 |accessdate=28 September 2018}} ==Personal life == [[File:Ruby Hunter and Archie Roach1.jpg|thumb|right|Roach (right) with [[Ruby Hunter]] at the 2009 [[Tamworth Country Music Festival]]]] Roach currently lives on a homestead near [[Berri, South Australia|Berri]], South Australia, with his children. His home has become something of a refuge for troubled Aboriginal youngsters, now dealing with some of the problems he himself faced.{{Citation needed|date=August 2008}} Roach is a supporter of [[Justice Action]], a criminal justice reform organisation based in Sydney, Australia. Roach's wife, [[Ruby Hunter]], died on 17 February 2010 aged 54. On 14 October 2010, Roach suffered a stroke while working in the [[Kimberley (Western Australia)|Kimberley]] region. After recuperating, he returned to live performance in April 2011. He has also survived lung cancer, due to early diagnosis in 2011 and major surgery.{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/local/stories/2012/11/05/3626089.htm|title= Into the Bloodstream, Archie Roach|publisher=ABC|date=5 November 2012|accessdate=28 September 2018}} == Awards and honours == ===ARIA Awards=== Roach has received five [[ARIA Music Awards]] from fourteen nominations.{{cite web|title=ARIA Awards - History|url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/search/?text=archie%20roach|publisher=Australian Record Industry Association|accessdate=6 April 2016}} {{awards table}} |- | Blues and Roots Album|ARIA Award for Best Blues and Roots Album]] || {{nom}} |- {{end}} === Other awards and honours === * Roach was one of the first people inducted to the Victorian Aboriginal HonourRoll in 2011.{{Cite web|url=https://www.vic.gov.au/aboriginalvictoria/community-engagement/leadership-programs/aboriginal-honour-roll/2011-victorian-aboriginal-honour-roll.html|title=2011 2017]] he won the Ted Albert Award for Outstanding Services to Australian Music.{{cite web | url = http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/7736658/archie-roach-australia-ted-albert-award-apra | title = [[Evelyn Stewart]] | music = Robby Poitevin | cinematography = [[Erico Menczer]] | editing = | released = {{Film date|1967}} | language = Italian | budget = }} '''''Assassination''''' is a 1967 Italian [[Thriller (genre)|thriller]]-[[spy film]] starring [[Henry Silva]]. It marked the directorial debut of [[Emilio Miraglia]].{{cite book|author1=Roberto Chiti |author2=Roberto Poppi |author3=Enrico Lancia |author4=Mario Pecorari |title=Dizionario del cinema italiano. I film|publisher=Gremese Editore, 1992|isbn=8876055932}}Marco Giusti. ''007 all'italiana''. Isbn Edizioni, 2010. {{ISBN|9788876381874}}. == Cast == * [[Henry Silva]] as John Chandler / Philip Chandler * Fred Beir as Bob * [[Ida Galli|Evelyn Stewart]] as Barbara * Peter Dane as Lang * Bill Vanders as Thomas * [[Alfredo Varelli|Fred Farrell]] as Morrison * Bob Molden as Otto * Karl-Heinz Menzinger as Hans * Gunther Scholtz as Senator * [[Valentino Macchi]] ==Reception== The Italian film critic Francesco Puma described the film as "ambiguous, crepuscular and uneasy" and as a Eurospy version of ''[[The Late Mattia Pascal]]''. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{IMDb title|0061367}} [[Category:1960s thriller films]] [[Category:1960s spy films]] [[Category:Italian thriller films]] [[Category:Italian spy films]] [[Category:Italian films]] [[Category:Films directed by Emilio Miraglia]] [[Category:Films set in the United States]] [[Category:Films set in Germany]] {{1960s-Italy-film-stub}}

{{about|the scrolling video game genre|the related genre for one-on-one combat|fighting game|the Iggy Pop album|Beat 'Em Up}} {{Redirect|Brawler|the 2011 American film|Brawler (film)|the 2017 Indian film|The Brawler}} {{Redirect|Brawlers|the English punk rock group|Brawlers (band)}} {{good article}} {{VG Action}}
'''Beat 'em up''' (also known as '''brawler''') is a [[Video game genres|video game genre]] featuring [[hand-to-hand combat]] between the protagonist and an improbably large number of opponents. Traditional beat 'em ups take place in [[Side-scrolling video game|scrolling]], [[2D computer graphics|two-dimensional]] (2D) levels, though some later games feature more open [[3D computer graphics|three-dimensional]] (3D) environments with yet larger numbers of enemies. These games are noted for their simple [[gameplay]], a source of both critical acclaim and derision. Two-player [[cooperative gameplay]] and multiple [[player character]]s are also hallmarks of the genre. Most of these games take place in urban settings and feature crime-fighting and revenge-based plots, though some games may employ historical, science fiction or fantasy themes.
The first beat 'em up was 1984's ''[[Kung-Fu Master (video game)|Kung-Fu Master]]'',<ref>{{cite web|url=https://books.google.co.jp/books?id=FdMnDwAAQBAJ&pg=PT51&dq=beat+em+up+kung+fu+master&hl=zh-TW&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi96Nb2od7YAhWGl5QKHS5QAmAQ6AEITTAF#v=onepage&q=beat+em+up+kung+fu+master&f=false|title=The A-Z of Atari 2600 Games: Volume 1|first=Kieren|last=Hawken|date=16 February 2017|publisher=Andrews UK Limited|accessdate=2 March 2018|via=Google Books}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/world-records/first-side-scrolling-beat-em-up|title=First side-scrolling beat-em-up|publisher=Guinness World Records|accessdate=2 March 2018}}</ref> with 1986's ''[[Renegade (video game)|Renegade]]'' introducing the urban settings and underworld revenge themes employed extensively by later games. The genre then saw a period of high popularity between the release of ''[[Double Dragon]]'' in 1987, which defined the two-player cooperative mode central to classic beat 'em ups, and 1991's ''[[Street Fighter II]]'', which drew gamers towards one-on-one [[fighting game]]s. Games such as ''[[Streets of Rage]]'', ''[[Final Fight (video game)|Final Fight]]'', ''[[Golden Axe (video game)|Golden Axe]]'' and ''[[Battletoads]]'' are other classics to emerge from this period. The genre has been less popular since the emergence of 3D-based mass-market games, but still some beat 'em ups adapted the simple formula to utilize large-scale 3D environments.
== Definition == [[File:Streets of Rage 2 action.png|thumb|Beat 'em ups, such as ''[[Streets of Rage 2]]'', feature combat against multiple antagonists, often taking place on modern city streets.]]
A beat 'em up (sometimes also called "brawlers")<ref>Thomas, Lucas M., [https://archive.is/20120715184926/http://videogames.yahoo.com/gba/justice-league-heroes-the-flash/review-1079564 Justice League Heroes: The Flash], ''Yahoo! Games'', Oct 27, 2007, Accessed Mar 22, 2009</ref><ref name="finalfight" /> is a type of [[action game]] where the player character must fight a large number of enemies in unarmed combat or with [[melee weapon]]s.<ref>Davis, Ryan, [http://reviews.cnet.com/xbox-games/the-hulk-xbox/4505-9582_7-30976135.html The Hulk (Xbox)], ''CNET'', May 5, 2003. Retrieved March 24, 2009.</ref><ref name="madworld1up">Ellis, David, [http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3173196&p=44 MadWorld Review for the Wii] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090326040113/http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3173196&p=44 |date=2009-03-26 }}, ''1UP'', March 10, 2009. Retrieved March 24, 2009.</ref><ref>Ashcraft, Brian, (2008) ''Arcade Mania! The Turbo-Charged World of Japan's Games Centers'', Kodansha International, p. 159</ref> Gameplay consists of walking through a [[Level (video gaming)|level]], one section at a time, defeating a group of enemies before advancing to the next section; a [[Boss (video gaming)|boss]] fight normally occurs at the end of each level.<ref>Navarro, Alex, [http://reviews.cnet.com/playstation-2-games/mcfarlane-s-evil-prophecy/4505-9581_7-30960404.html McFarlane's Evil Prophecy Game (PS2)], ''CNET'', June 15, 2004, Accessed Mar 27, 2009</ref> However arcade versions of these games are often quite difficult to win, causing players to spend more money.<ref>Navarro, Alex, [http://reviews.cnet.com/xbox-360-games/teenage-mutant-ninja-turtles/4505-11457_7-32365165.html Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (Xbox 360)], ''CNET'', Mar 14, 2007, Accessed Mar 27, 2009</ref>
Beat 'em ups are related to—but distinct from—fighting games, which are based around one-on-one matches rather than scrolling levels and multiple enemies.<ref name="tao1" /> Such terminology is loosely applied, however,<ref name="tao1" /> as some commentators prefer to conflate the two terms.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.edge-online.com/features/e3-feature-fighting-games-focus/|author=Anon.|title=E3 Feature: Fighting Games Focus|work=[[Edge (magazine)|Edge]]|publisher=[[Future plc]]|date=May 3, 2006|accessdate=2015-01-11}}</ref> At times, both one-on-one fighting games and scrolling beat 'em ups have influenced each other in terms of graphics and style and can appeal to fans of either genre.<ref name="tao1" /> Occasionally, a game will feature both kinds of gameplay.<ref>Wales, Matt, [http://wii.ign.com/articles/884/884590p2.html Super Smash Bros. Brawl UK Review], ''IGN'', June 8, 2008. Retrieved March 24, 2009.</ref>
In the United Kingdom, gaming magazines of the early 90s such as Mean Machines and Computer & Video Games (C+VG) refereed to all games which had a combat motif as beat 'em ups, even the fighting games.<ref>http://www.meanmachinesmag.co.uk/upload/media/scans/streetfighterguide.pdf</ref> However, they were differentiated by a specific prefix and so games like ''Double Dragon'' or ''Final Fight'' were called "scrolling beat 'em ups"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.meanmachinesmag.co.uk/review/405/final-fight.php |title=Final Fight – Super Nintendo – Mean Machines review |publisher=Meanmachinesmag.co.uk |date= |accessdate=2018-01-09}}</ref> and games such as ''Street Fighter II'' or ''[[Mortal Kombat]]'' were referred to as a "one on one beat 'em ups".
== Game design ==
Beat 'em up games usually employ vigilante crime fighting and revenge plots with the action taking place on city streets,<ref name="tao2" /> though historical and fantasy themed games also exist.<ref name="dynasty1up" /><ref name="goldenaxe" /> Players must walk from one end of the game world to the other,<ref name="gamespyhof" /> and thus each game level will usually scroll horizontally.<ref name="finalfight" /> Some later beat 'em ups dispense with [[2D computer graphics|2D]]-based scrolling levels, instead allowing the player to roam around larger [[3D computer graphics|3D]] environments, though they retain the same simple gameplay and control systems.<ref name="fightingforce" /><ref name="dynasty2" /> Throughout the level, players may acquire weapons that they can use as well as [[power-up]]s that replenish the player's [[Health (gaming)|health]].<ref name="finalfight" />
As players walk through the level, they are stopped by groups of enemies who must be defeated before they're able to continue.<ref>Nguyen, Thierry, [http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3173076&p=37 Watchmen: The End is Nigh (PS3)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090324230315/http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3173076 |date=2009-03-24 }}, ''1UP'', Mar 4, 2009, Mar 26, 2009</ref> The level ends when all the enemies are defeated. Each level contains many identical groups of enemies,<ref name="gamespyhof">Cassidy, William, [http://www.gamespy.com/articles/495/495400p1.html Hall of Fame: Golden Axe] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090818050558/http://www.gamespy.com/articles/495/495400p1.html |date=2009-08-18 }}, ''GameSpy'', June 8, 2003. Retrieved March 24, 2009.</ref><ref>Fudge, James, [http://xploder.net/xbox/reviews/379/X-Men-The-Official-Game-.htm X-Men: The Official Game] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081230122450/http://xploder.net/xbox/reviews/379/X-Men-The-Official-Game-.htm |date=December 30, 2008 }}, ''Xploder'' June 13, 2006. Retrieved March 24, 2009.</ref> making these games notable for their repetition.<ref name="gamespyhof" /><ref name="gamespymadworld">McGarvery, Sterling, [http://wii.gamespy.com/wii/madworld/961309p1.html Review – MadWorld (Wii)], ''GameSpy'', Mar 10, 2009, Accessed Mar 24, 2009</ref> In beat 'em up games, players often fight a [[boss (gaming)|boss]]—an enemy much stronger than the other enemies—at the end of each level.<ref name="finalfight" /><ref name="gamaboss">Ramachandran, Ryan, [http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=19005 Gamasutra Opinion: Boss Design – Trial & Punishment], ''GamaSutra'', June 17, 2008. Retrieved March 24, 2009.</ref>
Beat 'em ups often allow the player to choose between a selection of protagonists—each with their own strengths, weaknesses, and set of moves.<ref name="finalfight" /><ref name="goldenaxe" /><ref name="fightingforce" /><ref name="tmnt">Perry, Douglass C., [http://uk.xboxlive.ign.com/articles/772/772896p1.html Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles 1989 Arcade Review] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100926025431/http://uk.xboxlive.ign.com/articles/772/772896p1.html |date=2010-09-26 }}, ''IGN'', Mar 14, 2007, Accessed Mar 22, 2009</ref> Attacks can include rapid combinations of basic attacks ([[Combo (video gaming)|combos]]) as well as jumping and grappling attacks.<ref name="finalfight" /><ref name="tmnt" /> Characters often have their own [[Superpower (ability)|special attacks]], which leads to different strategies depending on which character the player selects.<ref>[http://superman.ugo.com/games/superman_death/ The Death and Return of Superman] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090819181305/http://superman.ugo.com/games/superman_death/ |date=August 19, 2009 }}, ''UGO'', 2006, Accessed Mar 27, 2009</ref> The control system is usually simple to learn, comprising as little as two buttons. These buttons can be combined to pull off [[Combo (gaming)|combos]], as well as jumping and grappling attacks.<ref name="finalfight" /><ref name="tmnt" /> Since the release of ''[[Double Dragon]]'', many beat 'em ups have allowed two players to play the game [[cooperative gameplay|cooperatively]]—a central aspect to the appeal of these games.<ref name="finalfight" /><ref name="tao2" /><ref name="goldenaxe" /><ref name="tmnt" /><ref name="beatemupcoop">Staff, [http://faqs.ign.com/articles/623/623396p1.html Game Help Editors' Picks Co-Op Games], ''IGN'', June 13, 2005. Retrieved March 24, 2009.</ref> Beat 'em ups are more likely to feature cooperative play than other game genres.<ref>Cifaldi, Frank, [http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/1719/the_quantum_leap_awards_the_most_.php The Quantum Leap Awards: The Most Important Multiplayer Games of All Time], ''GamaSutra'', Feb 2, 2007. Retrieved March 24, 2009.</ref>
== History == === Origin === The first game to feature fist fighting was [[Sega]]'s boxing game ''[[Heavyweight Champ (1976 arcade game)|Heavyweight Champ]]'' (1976),<ref name="tao1" /> which is viewed from a side-view perspective like later fighting games.<ref>Nadia Oxford, [http://www.1up.com/features/20-years-street-fighter 20 Years of Street Fighter], [[1UP.com]], 12/11/2007</ref> However, it was [[Data East]]'s fighting game ''[[Karate Champ]]'' (1984) which popularized martial arts themed games.<ref name="tao1">Spencer, Spanner, [http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/the-tao-of-beat-em-ups-article?page=2 The Tao of Beat-'em-ups], ''Eurogamer'', Feb 6, 2008, Accessed Mar 18, 2009</ref> The same year, [[Irem]]'s [[Hong Kong action cinema|Hong Kong cinema]]-inspired ''[[Kung-Fu Master (video game)|Kung-Fu Master]]'' (known as ''[[Wheels on Meals|Spartan X]]'' in Japan) laid the foundations for [[Side-scrolling video game|side-scrolling]] beat 'em ups with its simple gameplay and multiple enemies.<ref name="tao1" /><ref name="CGW">Kunkel, Bill; Worley, Joyce; Katz, Arnie, "The Furious Fists of Sega!", ''Computer Gaming World'', Oct 1988, pp. 48-49</ref> Also in 1984, ''[[Bruce Lee (video game)|Bruce Lee]]'' combined multi-player, multi-character combat with traditional collecting, platform and puzzle gameplay.<ref>{{cite journal |last= |first= |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=May 1985|title=''Bruce Lee'' review |journal=CRASH |volume= |issue=16 |pages= |id= |url=http://www.crashonline.org.uk/16/brucelee.htm |accessdate= 2007-09-26 |quote= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Edgely |first=Clare |authorlink= |coauthors= |date=May 1985 |title=Spectrum Software Scene 2 |journal=Sinclair User |volume= |issue=38 |pages= |id= |url=http://www.sincuser.f9.co.uk/038/sftwreb.htm |accessdate=2007-09-26 |quote= |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071105181811/http://www.sincuser.f9.co.uk/038/sftwreb.htm |archivedate=2007-11-05 |df= }}</ref> Later that year, ''[[Karateka (video game)|Karateka]]'' combined the one-on-one fight sequences of ''Karate Champ'' with the freedom of movement in ''Kung-Fu Master'', and it successfully experimented with adding plot to its fighting action. It was also among the first beat 'em ups to be successfully [[Porting|ported]] to home systems.<ref name="tao1" /> ''[[Renegade (video game)|Nekketsu Kōha Kunio-kun]]'', released in 1986 in Japan, deviated from the martial arts themes of earlier games and introduced street brawling to the genre. The Western adaptation ''Renegade'' (released the same year) added an underworld revenge plot that proved more popular with gamers than the principled combat sport of other games.<ref name="tao2">Spencer, Spanner, [http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/a_taoofbeatemups_pt2_retro The Tao of Beat-'em-ups (part 2)], ''EuroGamer'', Feb 12, 2008, Accessed Mar 18, 2009</ref> ''Renegade'' set the standard for future beat 'em up games as it introduced the ability to move both horizontally and vertically.<ref>[http://www.abc.net.au/tv/goodgame/stories/s2067970.htm Evolution of a Genre: Beat 'Em Ups],'' ABC Television'', Nov 6, 2007. Retrieved March 24, 2009.</ref> It also introduced the use of [[Combo (video gaming)|combo]] attacks; in contrast to earlier games, the opponents in ''Renegade'' and ''Double Dragon'' could take much more punishment, requiring a succession of punches, with the first hit temporarily immobilizing the enemy, making him unable to defend himself against successive punches.<ref name=1UP-Power>{{cite web|url=http://www.1up.com/do/feature?pager.offset=2&cId=3151392 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120718091646/http://www.1up.com/do/feature?pager.offset=2&cId=3151392 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=2012-07-18 |title=Playing With Power |page=3 |author=Jess Ragan |date=2006-06-15 |publisher=[[1UP.com]] |accessdate=2011-02-25 }}</ref>
=== Golden age === <!-- Deleted image removed: [[File:Double Dragon.png|thumb|The success of ''[[Double Dragon]]'' set the tone for numerous beat 'em ups to come, including its co-operative multiplayer gameplay.]] -->
In 1987, the release of ''[[Double Dragon]]'' ushered in a "Golden Age" for the beat 'em up genre that lasted nearly five years. The game was designed as [[Technōs Japan]]'s spiritual successor to ''Renegade'',<ref name="tao2" /> but it took the genre to new heights with its detailed set of martial arts attacks and its outstanding two-player [[cooperative gameplay]].<ref name="tao2" /><ref name="ddhof">Cassidy, William, [http://www.gamespy.com/articles/488/488826p1.html Hall of Fame: Double Dragon] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090818045122/http://www.gamespy.com/articles/488/488826p1.html |date=2009-08-18 }}, ''Gamespy'', Jan 5, 2003, Accessed, March 24, 2009</ref> ''Double Dragon'''s success resulted in a flood of beat 'em ups that came in the late 1980s,<ref name="ddhof" /> where acclaimed titles such as ''[[Golden Axe (video game)|Golden Axe]]'' and ''[[Final Fight (video game)|Final Fight]]'' (both 1989) distinguished themselves from the others.<ref name="tao2" /> ''Final Fight'' was [[Capcom|Capcom's]] intended sequel to ''[[Street Fighter]]'' (provisionally titled ''Street Fighter '89''),<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20080701021834/http://www.snk-capcom.com/didyouknow/archives/00000001.htm Did You Know? Volume 1: Street Fighter '89], [[Capcom]], Accessed Aug 17, 2009</ref> but the company ultimately gave it a new title.<ref name="kalata" /> In contrast to the simple combo attacks in ''Renegade'' and ''Double Dragon'', the combo attacks in ''Final Fight'' were much more dynamic, and the sprites were much larger.<ref name=1UP-Power /> Acclaimed as the best game in the genre,<ref name="finalfight">Navarro, Alex, [http://uk.gamespot.com/wii/action/finalfight/review.html Final Fight Review] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090707140056/http://uk.gamespot.com/wii/action/finalfight/review.html |date=2009-07-07 }}, ''GameSpot'', May 10, 2007, Accessed Mar 21 2009</ref><ref>Ashcraft, Brian, [http://kotaku.com/244633/clip-top-ten-beat-em-ups Clip: Top Ten Beat 'Em Ups] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090201032925/http://kotaku.com/244633/clip-top-ten-beat-em-ups |date=2009-02-01 }}, ''Kotaku'', Mar 16, 2007, Accessed Mar 21, 2009</ref> ''Final Fight'' spawned two home sequels and was later ported to other systems. ''Final Fight'' was also the reason for Capcom's new found fame and for Technos Japan's bankruptcy.<ref name="kalata">Kalata, Kurt, [http://www.hardcoregaming101.net/finalfight/finalfight.htm Final Fight], ''Hardcore Gaming 101'', Accessed Feb 04, 2010</ref> ''Golden Axe'' was acclaimed for its visceral [[hack and slash]] action and cooperative mode and was influential through its selection of multiple protagonists with distinct fighting styles.<ref name="goldenaxe">Kasavin, Greg, [http://uk.gamespot.com/wii/action/goldenaxegen/review.html Golden Axe Review] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070128205017/http://uk.gamespot.com/wii/action/goldenaxegen/review.html |date=2007-01-28 }}, ''GameSpot'', Dec 1, 2006, Accessed Mar 19, 2009</ref> It is considered one of the strongest beat 'em up titles for its fantasy elements, distinguishing it from the urban settings seen in other beat 'em ups.<ref name="gamespyhof" /> ''[[Bad Dudes Vs. DragonNinja]]'' featured platform elements, while ''[[P.O.W.: Prisoners of War]]'' took the weapon aspect a stage further, allowing the players to pick up guns. Another beat 'em up—''[[River City Ransom]]'' (1989), named ''Street Gangs'' in Europe—featured [[Role-playing video game|role-playing game]] elements with which the player's character could be upgraded, using money stolen from defeated enemies.<ref name="nintendo mag">"Rated Wii Shop", ''Nintendo: The Official Magazine'', September 2008 (issue 33), p. 129</ref><ref>[http://uk.top100.ign.com/2005/091-100.html IGN's Top 100 Games] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212073551/http://uk.top100.ign.com/2005/091-100.html |date=February 12, 2009 }}, ''IGN'', Accessed Mar 22, 2009</ref>
The ''[[Streets of Rage]]'' series was launched in the early 1990s and borrowed heavily from ''Final Fight''.<ref name="streetsofragehof">Cassidy, William, [http://www.gamespy.com/articles/488/488729p1.html Hall of Fame: Streets of Rage] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090818081217/http://www.gamespy.com/articles/488/488729p1.html |date=August 18, 2009 }}, ''GameSpy'', Sept 23, 2003, Accessed Mar 24, 2009</ref> ''[[Streets of Rage 2]]'' for Sega's [[Mega Drive]] was notable for being one of the first console games to match the acclaim of arcade beat 'em ups.<ref name="tao2" /> Its level design was praised for taking traditional beat 'em up settings and stringing them together in novel ways,<ref name="streetsofragehof" /> and its success led to it being ported to arcades.<ref name="tao2" /> The beat 'em up was also a popular genre for video games based on television series and movies, with ''[[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles (arcade game)|Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles]]'' and ''[[Batman Returns (video game)|Batman Returns]]'' a surprise success,<ref name="tao2" /> and encouraged many more beat 'em up games based on [[Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles|the characters]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://www.1up.com/do/feature?cId=3109998 | archive-url = https://archive.is/20120717082044/http://www.1up.com/do/feature?cId=3109998 | dead-url = yes | archive-date = 2012-07-17 | title = TMNT Games | publisher = 1up.com | accessdate = 2009-03-26 }}</ref> However, the "golden age" of the genre ended in the wake of the success of Capcom's ''[[Street Fighter II]]'' (1991), which drew gamers back towards one-on-one fighting games, while the subsequent emerging popularity of 3D video games diminished the popularity of 2D-based pugilistic games in general.<ref name="tao2" /><ref name="ddhof" /> By the mid-1990s, the genre suffered from a lack of innovation.<ref>Davis, Ryan, [http://reviews.cnet.com/wii-games/comix-zone-wii/1707-9993_7-32306339.html Comix Zone (Wii)], ''CNET'', Jan 31, 2007, Accessed Mar 27, 2009</ref>
=== 32-bit era onward === [[File:Zeno Clash - Fight.jpg|thumb|left|''[[Zeno Clash]]'' features beat 'em up gameplay from a [[first-person (video games)|first-person]] perspective]]
[[Core Design|Core Design's]] ''[[Fighting Force]]'' (1997) was anticipated to redefine the genre for 32-bit consoles through its use of a 3D environment. However, it was met with a lukewarm reception.<ref name="fightingforce">Gerstmann, Jeff, [https://archive.is/20130110221700/http://uk.gamespot.com/ps/action/fightingforce/review.html?om_act=convert&om_clk=gssummary&tag=summary;read-review Fighting Force Review], ''GameSpot'', Dec 1, 1997, Accessed Mar 19, 2009</ref> The ''[[Dynasty Warriors]]'' series, beginning with ''[[Dynasty Warriors 2]]'' in 2000, offered traditional beat 'em up action on large 3D battlefields, displaying dozens of characters on the screen at a time.<ref name="dynasty2">Sato, Ike, [https://archive.is/20130110222107/http://uk.gamespot.com/ps2/action/dynastywarriors2/review.html?om_act=convert&om_clk=gssummary&tag=summary;read-review Dynasty Warriors 2 Review], ''GameSpot'', Aug 17, 2000, Accessed Mar 19, 2009</ref><ref>Villoria, Gerald, [http://uk.gamespot.com/ps2/action/dynastywarriors3/review.html?om_act=convert&om_clk=gssummary&tag=summary;read-review Dynasty Warriors 3 Review] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110920025309/http://uk.gamespot.com/ps2/action/dynastywarriors3/review.html?om_act=convert&om_clk=gssummary&tag=summary%3Bread-review |date=September 20, 2011 }}, ''GameSpot'', Dec 18, 2001, Accessed Mar 19, 2009</ref> The series to date spans 14 games (including expansions) which players in the West view as overly similar, although the games' creators claim their large audience in Japan appreciates the subtle differences between the titles.<ref name="dynasty1up">Fitch, Andy, [http://arquivo.pt/wayback/20160522224653/http://www.1up.com/do/reviewPage?cId=3166358 Dynasty Warriors 6 (Xbox 360)], ''1UP'', Mar 7, 2008, Accessed Mar 19, 2009</ref><ref>Nutt, Christian, [http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=21080 Interview: How Koei Aims For Western Audiences], ''GamaSutra'', Dec 8, 2008, Mar 19, 2009</ref> While critics saw ''Dynasty Warriors 2'' as innovative and technically impressive,<ref name="dynasty1up" /><ref name="dynasty2" /> they held a mixed opinion of later titles. These later games received praise for simple, enjoyable gameplay but were simultaneously derided as overly simplistic and repetitive.<ref name="dynasty1up" /><ref>Ramsey, Randolph, [https://archive.is/20120719032649/http://uk.gamespot.com/ps3/action/shinsangokumusou5/review.html?om_act=convert&om_clk=gssummary&tag=summary;read-review Dynasty Warriors 6 Review], ''GameSpot'', Mar 28, 2008, Accessed Mar 18, 2009</ref> In 2000, Italian studio [[NAPS team]] released ''[[Gekido|Gekido: Urban Fighters]]'' for the PlayStation console, which uses a fast paced beat 'em up system, with many bosses and a colorful design in terms of graphics. Another best-selling Japanese series,<ref>Jenkins, David, [http://www.gamasutra.com/php-bin/news_index.php?story=22575 Japanese Charts: Yakuza 3 And Dynasty Warriors: Strikeforce Lead Busy Week], ''GamaSutra'', Mar 5, 2009, Accessed Mar 19, 2009</ref> ''[[Yakuza (series)|Yakuza]]'', combined elaborate plots and detailed interactive environments with street brawling action.<ref>Stanton, Rich, "Yakuza 2", ''Official Playstation Magazine UK'', Nov 2008 (issue 24), pp. 108-09</ref> Despite these releases, game reviewers started to pronounce that the genre had died off.<ref name="gamespyhof" /> By 2002, there were virtually no new beat 'em ups being released in arcades.<ref>Epperson, Justin, [http://www.1up.com/do/previewPage?cId=3157308&p=10 Die Hard Arcade EX: Asian Dynamite (Arcade)]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, ''1UP'', Feb 17, 2007, Accessed Mar 26, 2009</ref>
[[File:Guacamelee! screenshot B.jpg|thumb|right|''[[Guacamelee!]]'' is a brawling-based game based on [[luchador]]s fashioned after a ''[[Metroid]]''-style adventure game.]] Capcom's ''[[Viewtiful Joe]]'' (2003) used [[Cel-shaded animation|cel-shaded]] graphics and innovative gameplay features (such as the protagonist's special powers) to "reinvigorate" its traditional 2D scrolling formula.<ref>Bramwell, Tom [http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/r_viewtifuljoe_gc Viewtiful Joe], ''EuroGamer'', Oct 13, 2003, Accessed Mar 19, 2009</ref> [[The Behemoth]]'s ''[[Castle Crashers]]'' (2008) also featured cartoon graphics, quirky humor, and acclaimed cooperative gameplay.<ref>Francis, Don, [http://uk.gamespot.com/xbox360/action/castlecrashers/review.html Castle Crashers Review] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081202045120/http://uk.gamespot.com/xbox360/action/castlecrashers/review.html |date=December 2, 2008 }}, ''GameSpot'', Aug 28, 2008, Accessed Mar 26, 2009</ref> [[Rockstar Games]]' ''[[The Warriors (video game)|The Warriors]]'' (based on the [[The Warriors (film)|1979 movie]] of the same name), released in 2005, featured large scale brawling in 3D environments interspersed with other activities such as chase sequences.<ref name="warriors">Navarro, Alex, [http://uk.gamespot.com/ps2/action/warriors/review.html The Warriors Review] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090428182637/http://uk.gamespot.com/ps2/action/warriors/review.html |date=April 28, 2009 }}, ''GameSpot'', Oct 21, 2005, Accessed Mar 22, 2009</ref> The game also featured a more traditional side-scrolling beat 'em up ''Armies of the Night'' as bonus content, which was acclaimed along with the main game and was later released on the [[PlayStation Portable]].<ref name="warriors" /><ref>Cundy, Matt, [http://www.gamesradar.com/psp/the-warriors/news/rockstars-retro-beat-em-up-revealed/a-20070124151834484037/g-2006102517554345031 Rockstar's retro beat-'em-up revealed], ''GamesRadar'', Jan 24, 2007, Accessed Mar 22, 2009</ref> Releases such as ''[[God Hand]]'' in 2006 and ''[[MadWorld]]'' in 2009 were seen as [[parody|parodies]] of violence in popular culture, earning both games praise for not taking themselves as seriously as early beat 'em up games.<ref name="gamespymadworld" /><ref>Barnholt, Ray, [https://archive.is/20120727234357/http://www.1up.com/do/previewPage?cId=3152276&p=2 God Hand Preview], ''1UP'', July 17, 2006, Accessed Mar 26, 2009</ref> Classic beat 'em ups have been re-released on services such as the [[Virtual Console]]; critics reaffirmed the appeal of some,<ref name="finalfight" /><ref name="goldenaxe" /><ref name="nintendo mag" /> while the appeal of others has been deemed to have diminished with time.<ref name="tmnt" /> Although the genre lacks the same presence it did in the late 1980s, some titles such as ''Viewtiful Joe'' and ''God Hand'' kept the genre alive.<ref>"Clover Studios Wilts and Dies", ''GameAxis Unwired'', Nov 2006, p. 8</ref>
After 2000, the beat 'em up genre has seen a revival in the form of popular 3D [[hack and slash]] games in the style of ''[[Devil May Cry]]'' (2001 onwards), including ''[[Ninja Gaiden]]'' (2004 onwards), ''[[God of War (franchise)|God of War]]'' (2005 onwards), ''[[Heavenly Sword]]'' (2007), ''[[Afro Samurai (video game)|Afro Samurai]]'' (2009),<ref>{{cite web|title=Afro Samurai Review|publisher=PSX Extreme|date=2009-01-31|author=Arnold Katayev|url=http://www.psxextreme.com/ps3-reviews/216.html|accessdate=2011-02-26|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110715125840/http://www.psxextreme.com/ps3-reviews/216.html|archive-date=2011-07-15|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> and ''[[Bayonetta]]'' (2009).<ref>{{cite web|date=January 4, 2010|title=Bad hair day: Bayonetta hands-on|author=Jeff Bakalar, Scott Stein and Dan Ackerman|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-10424434-1.html|accessdate=2011-02-26}}</ref> Several traditional 2D scrolling beat 'em ups have also been released in recent years, including ''[[Scott Pilgrim vs. the World: The Game]]'' (2010).<ref>{{cite web|title=The Gamer’s Guide to Comic-Con 2010|author=Chris Kohler|date=July 22, 2010|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|url=https://www.wired.com/gamelife/2010/07/comic-con-games/|accessdate=2011-02-26}}</ref> The popular ''[[Grand Theft Auto]]'' series also has elements of the beat 'em up genre.{{fact|date=March 2017}}. ''[[Saints Row IV]]'' (2013) featured a parody of ''Streets Of Rage'' entitled "Saints Of Rage", where the player rescues [[Johnny Gat]] from a virtual prison.

[[File:William Haggars Bioscope1902.jpeg|thumb|right|250px|[[William Haggar]]'s travelling Bioscope from 1902]] A '''Bioscope''' show was a [[music hall]] and [[funfair|fairground]] attraction consisting of a travelling [[Movie theater|cinema]]. The heyday of the Bioscope was from the late 1890s until [[World War I]].
Bioscope shows were fronted by the largest [[fairground organ]]s,<ref>[http://www.steamfairground.co.uk/l3_bioscope.html "Hollycombe Steam Museum bioscope show"]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> and these formed the entire public face of the show. A stage was usually in front of the organ, and dancing girls would entertain the crowds between film shows.<ref>[http://www.fairground-heritage.org.uk/newsite/research/research-bioscopes.html "Fairground Heritage Trust"] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110703073622/http://www.fairground-heritage.org.uk/newsite/research/research-bioscopes.html |date=July 3, 2011 }}</ref>
Films shown in the Bioscope were primitive, and the earliest of these were made by the showmen themselves. Later, films were commercially produced.
Bioscope shows were integrated, in Britain at least, into the Variety shows in the huge Music Halls which were built at the end of the nineteenth century.
After the Music Hall Strike of 1907 in London, bioscope operators set up a trade union to represent them. There were about seventy operators in London at this point.
==Modern use== In South Africa "Bioscope" or in [[Afrikaans]] "bioskoop" is an archaic word for the cinema and some people (especially older generations) still use it regularly.
In modern day Dutch, "bioscoop" is a wide-spread term, and the equivalent of the English "movie theater" or "cinema".
